ETYMOLOGY: From Old French musique, from Latin mūsica 'art of music', from Ancient Greek mousikē (tekhnē) 'art of the Muses', from Mousa 'Muse'.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The art of arranging sounds in time to produce a composition having melody, harmony, rhythm, and timbre.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 一种通过安排声音在时间中的序列，以产生旋律、和声、节奏和音色等元素的艺术形式。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: She has been studying classical music for ten years.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 她学习古典音乐已经十年了。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Sounds that are melodious, harmonious, or rhythmic, whether composed or spontaneously produced.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 具有旋律、和声或节奏感的悦耳声音，无论是创作的还是自然产生的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: I could hear the music drifting from the open window.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 我能听到音乐从敞开的窗户飘出来。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A group of words established by usage as having a meaning not deducible from those of the individual words.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Something that is very pleasing or welcome to hear.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 令人非常高兴或乐意听到的事。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The news that the project was approved was music to my ears.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 项目获批的消息对我来说简直是天籁之音。
